intro: Turnera confertiflora, commonly known as the "Mexican buttercup," is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It belongs to the family Turneraceae and is characterized by its showy yellow flowers with five petals. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are opposite, simple, and often have a waxy texture, while its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in tropical and subtropical regions.
